[i][b]> Gameplay ( 6.0 / 10 ) :[/b][/i] a typical third-person shooter with MMO mechanics: take quests in a safe zone, explore buildings for useful items and zombies to kill, go back to the base to receive quest rewards, sell what you don‚Äôt need and leave again for another mission.
[i][b]Very basic levelling[/b][/i] system, skills give bonuses in combat. The ‚Äúhunger‚Äù for experience is the only reason to bear all those same and boring quests. Weapons and shooting work pretty well, nice variety in weapons, but they all feel the same.
[i][b]Looting[/b][/i] is totally random; you have to search hundreds of places for a tiny chance to find a useful item: for that, levels don‚Äôt matter at all.
Nice [i][b]players‚Äô market[/b][/i] to sell/buy items, but the only ones worth trading are meds, ammo and food. [i][b]Crafting is limited[/b][/i] to a few items (most of them are only for paying users) and requires rare or expensive objects.
The [i][b]map is too big[/b][/i] and travelling is a [i][b]waste of time[/b][/i]. There is a car, but it works only as a teleport between three zones. Even moving inside buildings is annoying (loadings at every door, huge quantity of empty rooms).
[i][b]Server issues[/b][/i] are quite frequent : a lot of lag, waiting for response, random disconnections and freezes.

[i][b]> Narrative ( 6.3 / 10 ) :[/b][/i] same clich√©s and usual stories about experiments, viruses and strange mutations.
We can find notes and documents that give us experience points and provide information about the whole story. Most of the writings lack details and depth, looking like useless texts.
Good [i][b]voice acting[/b][/i] for a reasonable number of lore items.

[i][b]> Aesthetics ( 5.6 / 10 ) :[/b][/i] the game offers a nice view of a decadent world; textures and models have a decent quality, the look of zombies and bosses is quite unique. Most of them are clearly assets directly taken from the market, as they have [i][b]no personality or detail[/b][/i].
[i][b]The map is uselessly huge, empty and repetitive[/b][/i]. Most of the locations are the same (probably some kind of random generation of rooms).
[i][b]Visual effects[/b][/i], like meteo or fog, look nice, but used to reduce rendering distance and improve not so good performance. They tried to give the world a gloomy aesthetic, but the feeling is of a world abandoned to laziness.

[i][b]> Sound ( 5.0 / 10 ) :[/b][/i] the sound design has been left to the [i][b]bare minimum[/b][/i]. Apart from the good sampling of weapons and zombie noises, DF2 doesn‚Äôt even try to fill the emptiness of its world. No ambient sounds, just a few objects reproducing the same audio tracks (like fires or radios). Some other sounds, like a random screaming woman, are instead very annoying, and it would have been better not to put them at all.
Same negative thoughts for the music too, lacking in variety and suffering from repetitiveness.

[i][b]> Challenge ( 5.8 / 10 ) :[/b][/i] as many other free MMOs, DF2 tries to stretch as much as possible the whole game experience. Half the time you spend it on travelling, the other half is spent killing dozens of zombies that get in your way.

The total randomness in items means [i][b]no real progression or ability[/b][/i], only too much grinding to find what you need. In fact, the difficulty of the game is to find the best weapons‚Äô stats and trying to level up as quickly as possible.
Most [i][b]zombies are idiots[/b][/i], and they hit you only due to some bug or error (like a tiny chair blocking your way). Bosses take time to beat because you need to hit-and-run for five minutes while spreading tons of ammo.

Ok, let's review this game first. 

In short, this game is a free shooter looter MMORPG with strong early resident evil vibes (Racoon city) and a touch of silent hill atmosphere sometimes specially outdoors. The combat also reminds me of State of Decay 1 big time but way less focus on survival elements here and more on the shooting and the looting. Its like Resident Evil, State of Decay and Diablo had a 3rd person shooter love child.

The game does indeed get repetitive with the grind but I think the dev did a great job with the atmosphere here and instances do look varied depending on the building/establishment so houses will have a different look from restaurants and so on. The game's lore is mostly known through lore notes and tape records you loot as you do missions and grind. It adds to the immersion and atmosphere big time. There are no cinematics so far, its all live and on the go which fits the fastpaced gameplay of looter games but also without compromising the atmosphere.

It does have some jank and instance corridors can branch way too much for my liking that the grind can feel rather repetitive and it is also way too overly dark outdoors for my liking specifically at night and it could still use some more QoL here and there
BUT it does have its own charm and I can see lots of passion put into this project. I heard the game is made by a solo dev and I still see the dev updates this game and continues working on it even after 7 years and I've got to say I always respect devs who respect their project.
Note that this also a game that doesn't hold your hand. Its very old school in that sense.

The community has been so chill so far and they remind me of good old internet days and you can't imagine howmuch I appreciate that personally but then the dev went a step ahead and also implemented a singleplayer mode. 
Worth noting that the community on the game's official discord has been extra helpful as well and they've been welcoming and nice.

This game is even more fun with friends, too and guess what? It also has a coop mode where you can host a room (with password if you like) to play alone with friends so the game has an MMO mode, a coop hosted game mode and a singleplayer mode and your progress is saved across all of them.

Afaik, the game is also not high on requirements and can work on potato PCs well. There are lots of graphical options and resolution options.

For those curious, here's a little history of my personal experience with this game, I think the first time I played the prequel to this game (Dead Frontier 1) was like on 2012 or so. I really liked the concept of a free to play zombie shooter MMO at the time which was not a very common thing and is still not that common to date either. However, back then, I couldn't get into the game because, I was still a kid and I didn't know how resource management (specially when it comes to Ammo) works in survival games so I left it for a long time since then. 

Fast forward several years later, I saw Dead Frontier 2 on steam and it caught my interest then I realized its the sequel to the older game Dead Frontier 1 but 3rd person instead of isomteric this time. I wanted to try it out but at the time, I had a potato PC and was scared if it might not run smooth then skipping a few years later and on around 2023, I had a better PC by then so I gave it a try and I've been playing it fairly casually since then. Dead frontier 2 was a collasal mistake, and part of it isint even neil's fault.

To understand we need to flash back to the time shortly before dead frontier 2 is born, sometime in 2017.
most of the ideas for zombies, and monsters that inspire the dead frontier games come from the resident evil franchise this is well known, but of course in 2017 resident evil had its first major reboot as a franchise, shying away from the action combat zombie game it was, to focus more on the horror aspect. no longer are you chris redfield spin kicking a 25 foot tall tendril monster with 4 arms and shooting a grenade launcher at its head blowing it up, your a random normal guy named ethan armed with a pocket knife, and a small pistol cauciosly making his way through a large farm house. This massive change clearly left its mark on neil, and because of that dead frontier as a franchise suffered, because neil figured if copying resident evil worked well before, there was no reason it couldnt work again, not realizing that kind of change is very hard to pull off, which is how dead frontier goes from 3d, players backpedaling at super human speed through a parking lot firing a minigun at 3 titanic zombies armorer in bone from head to toe whilst on fire, To a random guy in a beanie using the worlds weakest 12 gauge to shoot a zombie thats slower then a 3 year old. You can see where im going with this. dead frontier, and dead frontier 2 are completly different games from the ground up, as different as mario kart is from super mario world, both mario, but utterly different. and it just doesn't work in dead frontier 2. The BIGGEST problem by far, and the choice that still haunts the game is the over the shoulder combat choice. df3d was a birds eye view top down shooter for over 10 years. which meant neil had zero experience in this form of design, and it shows, combat feels rough, made even worse by the sheer lack of threat from most zombies, which in 3d were an overwhelming force of nature, a near hive mind level threat that was ever present. in df2 they feel almost static. Another very large problem is the ui, god help the ui because its 1 of the worst ive seen in a hot minute, it need a full redesign, namely inventory and the marketplace, which if im being honest idk why neil didint copy his own work from df3d since it already worked well there. even if it didint want the cell based inventory design thats fine, keep the look, and core design.

There is a lot more that can be said about this game, such as neil already got the message from fans, that they prefer the original df3d game over df2, and that he will focus development to the og game over df2 so this things already on the backburner, or that 90% of the players no longer speak english which is a strange turn of events, there is some good that can be said about this game.
